awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GABA A Receptor Control of Hyperactivity in Developing Zebrafish
awd_abstract_narration:
Walking and swimming are produced by the coordinated activity of brain cells called neurons that communicate with each other using chemical signals known as neurotransmitters. The chemical signals are passed from one neuron to another across a network of neurons in the brain, then on to neurons in the spinal cord, and finally, the signal is passed to muscles. Some neurotransmitters increase neuron activity, whereas others decrease neuron activity. It is not known how different neurotransmitters balance their effects to coordinate neuron network activity and enable normal locomotion. The goal of this project is to investigate the role of one particular neurotransmitter in the brain to better understand how it regulates locomotion. The project will be carried out using zebrafish because this vertebrate animal has a more simple brain and spinal cord organization than mammals, and it is transparent, which makes it easy to examine under a microscope. Due to the many similarities in neurotransmitters and locomotor networks between zebrafish and mammals, this work can have wide-reaching implications. This project is a collaboration between four faculty researchers from three colleges.  Undergraduates at each institution will participate in the research and have access to the expertise across institutions. The research team, including faculty, graduate and undergraduate students, will perform teaching demonstrations about neuroscience at nearby middle and high schools, and students from these schools will visit the investigators' laboratories. Through this outreach effort, 300-600 primarily underrepresented minority middle and high school students will be exposed to scientists and neuroscience. 

The central hypothesis that will be tested in this project is that, during early larval stages, a limited number of gamma amino butyric acid (GABA) type  A receptor isoforms regulate locomotor networks through a small number of hindbrain reticulospinal neurons. To test this hypothesis, the expression of GABA-A receptor subunits will be determined, the effects of genetic inactivation of GABA-A receptor subunits on locomotor network activity and behavior will be investigated, and the contribution of select hindbrain neurons in generating GABA-A receptor-mediated hyperactive behavior will be assessed.  These studies will be carried out in genetically modified zebrafish using microscopy, electrophysiological recordings, quantitative analysis of locomotor behavior, and a novel photochemical approach that enables control of specific GABA-A receptors using different wavelengths of light.

por.por_cntn:
Primarily an inhibitory neurotransmitter throughout the nervous system, GABA is important to control many aspects of brain and spinal cord function, including those neural networks that generate locomotor behaviors, such as walking or swimming. GABA exerts its effects through its receptors, GABAA and GABAB, with the former mediating rapid responses to GABA. Although GABAA receptors are known to be important to control locomotion, the diversity of receptor types and the complexities of mammalian nervous systems have challenged efforts to identify how each controls locomotion. In the completed study, we established the developing zebrafish as a system to investigate how different types of GABAA receptors control locomotion. Larval zebrafish harbor a more simple vertebrate brain and spinal cord compared to mammals, are a leading system for neural circuit analysis, and they perform robust swimming behaviors. We determined that zebrafish contain a similar diversity of GABAA receptors as mammalian systems, with most mammalian types having a clear zebrafish version. We also elucidated where a subset of GABAA components, called subunits, are located within the larval zebrafish brain and spinal cord. To investigate how these subunits control locomotion, we inactivated different GABAA receptors subunits, alone and in various paired combinations. We then designed and used computer programs to analyze swimming behaviors. We found that some subunits selectively controlled one parameter of swimming behavior while others selectively controlled a different aspect of swimming behavior. Taken together, this is a important step forward to understand how the diversity of GABAA receptors regulate swimming behavior. Surprisingly, as zebrafish larvae continue to develop, normal swimming patterns emerged, regardless of which subunits where inactivated. This finding suggests that the nervous system has a robust ability to compensate for loss of inhibitory neurotransmitter signaling. Given similarities in where GABAA receptors are located in the brain and spinal cord across species, our studies in zebrafish suggest mechanisms for how these receptors regulate locomotion in other vertebrates. This project also had a variety of broader impacts. We had college students from three different institutions work on this project during summers to expose them to scientific research, hosted lab visits for high school and community college students, and visited elementary, middle and high schools to discuss who we are as scientists and this research project. Our efforts impacted roughly 827 students, mostly from lower socioeconomic backgrounds. Many of these efforts would not have been possible without the support provided by this project.
